comment._content: At Angies:  I'm thinking the statue thing is deliberate.  The pose and the leaf are replicating a statue and they've probably covered him in powder.

comment.author: 10737476@N05
comment._content: Eugene Sandiow became a major star at the 1893 World's Fair  in Chicago where he was promoted by Lorenz Ziegfeld later the legendary Follies and stage producer.  A series of cards were produced and sold.  They were so popular that many women purchased and displayed them in their living rooms with other family pictures.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I saw this via www.indicommons.org/2012/04/02/april-2-eugen-sandow-1867-... I recently found an image of Sandow in a small Edwardian album. There were other images that suggested the owner of the album (and I think the photographer) aspired to be like him ... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture/6597206351/][http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture/6378725735/]

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: How interesting, whatsthatpicture!  Such an insight into the albumkeeper's personality, just from the juxtaposition of photos.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] it was funny seeing my own comment - I had always made the connection between the Sandow photo and the picture (possibly a self portrait) of John Hook but never until tonight actually placed them side by side.  As you say, it makes for an interesting comparison.
